title: Dictionary<TKey, TValue> (The Lookup Table)
simplifierConcept:
Imagine a real dictionary: You look up a WORD (the key) and get its DEFINITION (the value). You don't flip through page by page - you jump straight to the word!

A Dictionary<TKey, TValue> works the same way! It stores KEY-VALUE PAIRS:
• The KEY is unique (like a word - only appears once)
• The VALUE is what you get when you look up that key
• Lookup is INSTANT - no matter how big the dictionary!

Examples:
• Phone book: Name (key) → Phone number (value)
• Game: PlayerName (key) → Score (value)
• Store: ProductID (key) → Price (value)

Why not use a List? Lists require you to search through items one by one. Dictionaries use the key for INSTANT lookup - like using an index in a book!

Perfect for when you need to find things by a unique identifier!

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: Two types in angle brackets: TKey (key type) and TValue (value type). Dictionary<string, int> means string keys, int values.
Adds a key-value pair. The key MUST be unique! Trying to add the same key twice causes an error.
Get or set a value by its key. dict['Alice'] gets Alice's value. dict['Alice'] = 100 sets it. If key doesn't exist, CRASH!
Check if a key exists BEFORE accessing it! Always check first to avoid crashes: if (dict.ContainsKey('x')) { use dict['x'] }
Loop through key-value pairs. Each 'pair' has .Key and .Value properties. Order is NOT guaranteed!

challenge.instructions:
Create a simple English-Spanish translator!

1. Create Dictionary<string, string> called 'translator'
2. Add translations: 'hello' → 'hola', 'goodbye' → 'adiós', 'friend' → 'amigo'
3. Look up and display the translation for 'hello'
4. Check if 'goodbye' exists, then display its translation
5. Add a new translation: 'water' → 'agua'
6. Use foreach to display all translations in format: 'English: Spanish'
challenge.hint: Create: Dictionary<string, string> dict = new Dictionary<string, string>(); Add: dict.Add(key, value); Access: dict[key]; Check: ContainsKey(key)
commonStickingPoints: Duplicate keys: Adding the same key twice throws an error! Use ContainsKey to check first, or use dict[key] = value which updates if exists.
Accessing non-existent key: dict['xyz'] when 'xyz' doesn't exist = CRASH! Always use ContainsKey first!
Wrong foreach syntax: foreach (string x in dict) is wrong! Use foreach (var pair in dict) then access pair.Key and pair.Value.
Forgetting two types: Dictionary<string> is WRONG! Need TWO types: Dictionary<TKey, TValue> like Dictionary<string, int>.
